Mewes’s current research is in the area of spintronics, focusing on materials design, optimization, analysis, and modeling for spin-transfer-torque magnetic random-access memories (STT-MRAM) and non-volatile (NV) spin logic. She holds a provisional patent on low-frequency-noise detection. Dr. Mewes has also worked in the field of quantum computing (for her PhD), investigating decoherence-free subspaces and error-correction protocols in many-body systems. Dr. Mewes received her PhD from the University of Kaiserslautern in Germany in 2004. Dr. Mewes was a postdoctoral researcher from 2005-2006 at Ohio State University and at the University of Alabama since 2006. In 2009, she became an adjunct professor of the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Theoretical and experimental aspects of the research are carried out under the leadership of Dr. Claudia Mewes and Dr. Tim Mewes respectively. In addition to equipment operated by the Center for Materials for Information Storage Technology ( MINT ) and the Central Analytical Facilities ( CAF ) here at the  University of Alabama our group has unique capabilities aimed at the theoretical and experimental investigation of the magnetization dynamics of materials and devices. Research in our laboratory has been funded by NSF, DARPA, NASA and a number of industry partners.
